reviewText:
Nostalgic.
Back in the day when I was little, I used to own the PS1 version of this game. I loved the crap out of it.
To this day, it's still fairly cute and cartoony. The puzzles are fair for kids and they should be able to handle most of it. Heck, some of it is actually quite challenging even for a kids game.
So yeah, if you have young kids and they like video games, play this series. They (and you) won't regret it.

date: it's time for dinner!" Not feeling quite hungry for a meal

Fans who have not played this game yet will love the cameo appearances. The carrot from the first Pajama Sam game makes a return. There's also Sprinkles the Donut who helps Sam travel. (It reminds me from Otto from PS1).

reviewText:
When I found out recently that Pajama Sam 3 is on steam, I immediately bought it as I can finally complete the game as I was not able to when I was a kid. It gave me a chance to finally have a closure to one of my favourite childhood game.

Throughout the game, it gave me a very nostalgic feeling as we've been constantly playing games of high graphical quality, contrasting a lot with the graphics of games used in the 2000, making me enjoy every moment of it.

Even though this game is recommended to kids of ages 3-8, it doesn't seem that way as I'm sure that there are many adults here that would like to ride the nostalgia train and enjoy the game like how we used to when we were kids. Playing it as an adult sometimes surprises me at times as I remembered completing a particular stage of the game as a kid, but was stuck at it for a while when replaying it as an adult. I'm proud that I've not succumbed to the temptation of reading guides when I'm stucked since guides of any games are so readily available everywhere on the internet now. I mean, there ain't many guides when I was a kid and I almost completed the game. Even if there is, I doubt I know how to surf the internet at that age.

To those that have played the game before as a kid, but have never completed it before, or simply just want to play the game for nostalgic purposes, it is worth every penny to buy the game.

An Instant Childhood Point-and-Click Classic from the Days of my Childhood, which consist of the old MS-DOS, Windows 3.1, Windows 95, Windows 98 & Windows 98SE PCs in which you help Pajama Sam rescue the 4 Food Group Delegates & hold an mergency peace conference & Mop Top Island where conflict is taking place between healthy and junk food.

[Previously on Pajama Sam]
Sam: Not so fast, evil doer. It's jail for you, you tasty villain!

(Sam is talking to a cookie, which he eats.)

You and your chocolate chip gang are through!

(Sam says as he eats the rest of the cookies, leans back and realizes)

Boy, eating cookies is hard work!

(He rips the box top off of the box of cookies and puts it on his pile of box tops.)

Ah, but there's only one more box to go and I'll have twenty box tops!

And that means I can get the Pajama Man action figure with titanic elbow thrust!

I can hardly wait!

reviewText: In the third installment of the Pajama Sam series, Sam eats his way through several boxes of cookies in order to collect the right amount of box tops in exchange for a Pajama Man action figure. Right when he opens the final box, all of the cookies come jumping out and storm into the kitchen. Sam knows they were up to no good and decides to trial them as Pajama Sam". Upon entering the kitchen Sam soon enters yet another world of his imagination inside the kitchen storage room which is a gateway to a food world. All six food groups of the world aren't in peace with each other and the only ones who can stablize peace are the food delicates of each food group. It's up to Sam to prevent a war from breaking out. Unlike in the previous two games
date: Sam isn't over coming any fears in this game
recommended: instead it's about preventing war and learning about the food groups as he progresses his mission. The story is just as inventive as the previous installments and the characters and jokes once again are clever and well thought out. If you love the last two Pajama Sam games
hoursPlayed: then you can't go wrong with this one."

reviewText: In the year 2000, while some people were playing games like Counter-Strike, the real hardcore gamers – my five-year old self included – were playing Pajama Sam 3. Every time our ignorant parents would accuse us of rotting our brains away by playing video games, we could point to the latest Pajama Sam title and show how we were teaching ourselves about balanced nutrition and international negotiations simultaneously in Sam’s latest adventure. Pajama Sam 3 is as good as it gets: featuring a quest to unite all the food groups and prevent total war (take notes, world leaders: diplomacy does work), a sidequest to collect enough box tops to win a Pajama Man action figure (does anyone else remember collecting these for school fundraisers as a kid?) and a cameo of everyone’s favorite hippie anarchist carrot (the diehard Pajama Sam fans will go crazy for this one), Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head to Your Feet is a masterpiece from beginning to end. Even if you aren’t a lifelong Pajama Sam fan and can’t experience a jolt of nostalgia like everyone else, you at least owe it to yourself to play Pajama Sam 3 today so you can at least pretend to be as cool as we were fifteen years ago.

reviewText:
That was pretty good. I'm glad Humongous got back on track for Pajama Sam.

I don't think companies should stick to a solid formula if they create a franchise. Nintendo has managed to evolve the Mario franchise over the years, but with very few distinct changes. That's honestly one of the biggest problems with series. How far do you go to make a sequel distinct and different, while also keeping the same general formula of your previous installment(s)?

I think Pajama Sam 3 did alright. I liked what it did. It was different, but it was still distinctly a Pajama Sam.

The story is similar to the other installments, where Sam has a problem and some supernatural imaginative event carries Sam to a separate world where he learns the error of his ways. Although, this is the first time in the series where Sam doesn't deal with a fear: it's more or less a personal flaw of overeating.

The world, much like the Land of Darkness from the first game, is incredibly imaginative. It's a massive rendition of Sam's body, as he goes around and restores balance" to the food groups. There's no B.S
date: random conflict that comes out of nowhere. No random World Wide Weather business complex. It's simple imagination- like the first Pajama Sam.\n\nBut
recommended: despite what good things there are
hoursPlayed: there are still plenty of bad things. The mini-games are absolutely awful. I hate the bean-sorting game and the ski slopes. And some puzzles were a little vague
voteText: especially if the game was made for kids. Like specifically finding the sand castle for the bag to fill for the Cheese Delegate guy. And
helpfulPercent: the voice actress for Florette the Broccoli sounds like she's just reading a paper in front of her face.\n\nHowever
votesHelpful: the game follows the original Pajama Sam formula
votesTotal: without using the first game as a crutch
votesFunny: like Pajama Sam 2 did. It tells a new story with new characters
column18: and story of personal growth that the original game created. And I enjoyed the time I spent playing it. I'm giving this one a 7/10."

reviewText: This is an interesting review, coming from someone who grew up playing and loving the first two games, but having never played the third one until now. That said
date: I had fun with the game
recommended: but I think some of it is because it reminds me of the first two games
hoursPlayed: so it's still indirectly influenced by nostalgia. YMMV."
